content:
A ass="word-wrap-span">BABY ass="word-wrap-span">GAZES up at ass="word-wrap-span">The camera, her brown eyes full of wonder. ass="word-wrap-span">Friends and relatives cuddle and play with her, singing soothing lullabies. ass="word-wrap-span">The group sits in ass="word-wrap-span">The dark, dusty basement of a makeshift hospital that ass="word-wrap-span">The child’s faass="word-wrap-span">Ther, Hamza, runs; bombs are raining down outside. It is ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo in ass="word-wrap-span">The summer of 2016. ass="word-wrap-span">Much of ass="word-wrap-span">The first year of Sama’s life has been spent in this way.

ass="word-wrap-span">For five years Waad Al-Kateab, Sama’s moass="word-wrap-span">Ther, filmed her experience of ass="word-wrap-span">The civil war in ass="word-wrap-span">Syria, a conflict which has claimed 500,000 lives and displaced millions more. ass="word-wrap-span">Protests against ass="word-wrap-span">The government of Bashar al-ass="word-wrap-span">assad, ass="word-wrap-span">The president, began in 2011 and by 2012 rebels had seized parts of ass="word-wrap-span">Syria’s largest city. Ms Al-Kateab was 18 years old at ass="word-wrap-span">The time, studying economics at ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo ass="word-wrap-span">University. ass="word-wrap-span">The regime denied that ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Protests were happening and ass="word-wrap-span">She felt a duty to record ass="word-wrap-span">The revolution, working as a citizen journalist ass="word-wrap-span">For ass="word-wrap-span">Channel 4, a British broadcaster. ass="word-wrap-span">She would weave through demonstrations and film soldiers beating up civilians, shouting “ass="word-wrap-span">Look! ass="word-wrap-span">Look! ass="word-wrap-span">Don’t tell me you can’t see ass="word-wrap-span">Them!”

“I thought I would be killed,” ass="word-wrap-span">She says, yet “the footage would be evidence of what it looked like in ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo during the war.” ass="word-wrap-span">She survived but ass="word-wrap-span">After six months under siege, and on the advice of the ass="word-wrap-span">United ass="word-wrap-span">Nations, ass="word-wrap-span">She fled the country with her family in December 2016. ass="word-wrap-span">After arriving in ass="word-wrap-span">Britain, Ms Al-Kateab met Edward ass="word-wrap-span">Watts, a film-maker, and they decided to collaborate on a film. Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Watts describes it as being a “gift from the gods”: “ass="word-wrap-span">This was the film that I’d dreamt of making, and here it was with ass="word-wrap-span">This incredible woman and ass="word-wrap-span">This incredible story.”

ass="word-wrap-span">They edited Ms Al-Kateab’s footage down from 300 hours to 95 minutes, and what remains is “ass="word-wrap-span">For Sama”, a grim portrait of ass="word-wrap-span">The brutality of ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">assad regime. ass="word-wrap-span">Mangled corpses lie on ass="word-wrap-span">The ground. ass="word-wrap-span">People choke on chlorine gas. ass="word-wrap-span">Children’s faces—bloody and studded with shrapnel—look down Ms Al-Kateab’s lens. ass="word-wrap-span">Two young boys watch as doctors search in vain ass="word-wrap-span">For ass="word-wrap-span">Their broass="word-wrap-span">Ther’s pulse: ass="word-wrap-span">The four-year-old had been playing in ass="word-wrap-span">The street outside his home when an airstrike hit. ass="word-wrap-span">The broass="word-wrap-span">Thers kiss him goodbye, tears streaming down ass="word-wrap-span">Their dusty cheeks, and ass="word-wrap-span">Their moass="word-wrap-span">Ther carries him out of ass="word-wrap-span">The hospital in a body bag. Ms Al-Kateab imagines herself as a grieving moass="word-wrap-span">Ther. In a voiceover, softly spoken in Arabic, she asks: “Sama, ass="word-wrap-span">Will you remember ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo? ass="word-wrap-span">Will you blame me ass="word-wrap-span">For staying here? Or blame me ass="word-wrap-span">For leaving?”

ass="word-wrap-span">The film shows Hamza’s hospital—eventually ass="word-wrap-span">The only hospital left in ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo—being bombed and forced to relocate to anoass="word-wrap-span">Ther building. ass="word-wrap-span">Over 20 days ass="word-wrap-span">The doctors ass="word-wrap-span">There perform 890 operations and receive more than 6,000 wounded. ass="word-wrap-span">The floor is ass="word-wrap-span">always cass="word-wrap-span">Overed in blood. Ms Al-Kateab says that when she closes her eyes she sees nothing but red.

ass="word-wrap-span">There are moments of fleeting happiness, even in a warzone. Ms Al-Kateab’s wedding to Hamza is a low-key affair, with balloons, confetti and singing and dancing that drowns out ass="word-wrap-span">The sound of explosions. ass="word-wrap-span">The birth of Sama in 2016 is a joyous event, if tinged with sadness for ass="word-wrap-span">The friends ass="word-wrap-span">They have lost. ass="word-wrap-span">There is evidence of human resilience, too. ass="word-wrap-span">Old men sit and play chess ass="word-wrap-span">amongst ass="word-wrap-span">The rubble while children play in ass="word-wrap-span">The burnt-out shell of a bus. ass="word-wrap-span">Schools carry on teaching in ass="word-wrap-span">Their basements. A boy says he wants to become an architect, “so I can rebuild ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo”.

ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Film won ass="word-wrap-span">Best ass="word-wrap-span">Documentary at ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Cannes ass="word-wrap-span">Film ass="word-wrap-span">Festival and has been screened at ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">United ass="word-wrap-span">Nations ass="word-wrap-span">For ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Security ass="word-wrap-span">Council as evidence of ass="word-wrap-span">The atrocities committed by ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">assad regime against ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Syrian people. ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Film-makers would like “ass="word-wrap-span">For Sama” to be shown to ass="word-wrap-span">The Russian government. “ass="word-wrap-span">The Russians are ass="word-wrap-span">The ones who have kept ass="word-wrap-span">The regime alive,” Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Watts says. “ass="word-wrap-span">This ass="word-wrap-span">Film is like an empathy machine: it allows people to experience what’s happened in ass="word-wrap-span">Syria through Waad’s eyes and maybe that can even touch ass="word-wrap-span">The cold heart of ass="word-wrap-span">Vladimir Putin.”

ass="word-wrap-span">Today, Ms Al-Kateab lives in London with her family. Sama, now three years old, has been joined by a little sister, Taima, aged two. ass="word-wrap-span">Will they ever return to their home country? “ass="word-wrap-span">When things are different on the ground, and the regime is out of power, we ass="word-wrap-span">Will all die to be back.” ass="word-wrap-span">But the war is not over, Ms Al-Kateab laments: the regime continues to bomb Idlib, the last rebel stronghold.

ass="word-wrap-span">But Sama brings hope, and that is why the film is dedicated to her. “Sama” means sky in Arabic; Ms Al-Kateab says that it represents the sky they long ass="word-wrap-span">For, one with no warplanes, just sun, clouds and birds. “ass="word-wrap-span">For Sama” is a love letter, not just from mother to daughter, ass="word-wrap-span">But to ass="word-wrap-span">Aleppo and its people.

“ass="word-wrap-span">For Sama” is released in select cinemas on ass="word-wrap-span">September 13th. It will be screened on ass="word-wrap-span">Channel 4 in the autumn
